item.title: How to price a product, sell it to customers, and build a sales team
item.description:
Each week, we invite an industry leader to host a Q&A session with the Stripe Atlas Community. Steli Efti, cofounder and CEO of Close.io, recently answered questions from founders in Stripe¬†Atlas.

What cold email subject lines lead to the highest open¬†rates?

First, a caveat. I‚Äôve seen really high open rates, in the 80 percent range, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that those emails were ultimately successful. One of the best subject lines I ever received from a salesperson was the subject line ‚ÄúReally disappointed‚Ä¶‚Äù and when I saw that, I instantly thought: ‚ÄúWhat did we mess up? What did I do wrong? What happened here?‚Äù It was the first email I opened after a long vacation. I had hundreds and hundreds of emails, but that one stood¬†out.

The subject line was ‚ÄúVery disappointed‚Ä¶‚Äù and then the body of the email continued, ‚Äú‚Ä¶that we haven‚Äôt been able to connect. I called you multiple times because our web development shop‚Ä¶‚Äù I thought: ‚ÄúMother effer, you got me to open the email‚Äù, and then I deleted it, because if the first thing that starts our relationship is you tricking me into opening your email, that‚Äôs not going to make me trust you and want to¬†continue.

I could make the subject line ‚ÄúI have your parents in my basement‚Äù and it would get a very high open rate. Even people whose parents aren‚Äôt alive anymore would open that email. But that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs going to translate into a customer¬†relationship.

That said, a healthy benchmark to aim for‚Äîif you don‚Äôt use any trickery‚Äîis somewhere between 30-40%. If you can get that in outbound emails, that‚Äôs very, very good. If your open rate is below 15%, then you‚Äôre in trouble, and I would focus on improving your subject line before doing anything¬†else.

What are the characteristics of great cold¬†emails?

A great cold email clearly and concisely answers the right questions at the right time, and it ends with a single call to¬†action.

The subject line both piques somebody‚Äôs curiosity and promises something that the body of the email will deliver. If I‚Äôm receiving your email, I read the subject line and I think: ‚ÄúHuh, what is this about?‚Äù So I open it. Your body text needs to immediately answer the questions in my mind: Who is this? What do you want from me? Of all of the people in the world, why did you reach out to¬†me?

If you answer those questions well, each one of your sentences makes me think: ‚ÄúOkay, this is who this person is, this is what they do, and this is why they think this is important to¬†me.‚Äù

You need to end your cold email with a single, specific call to action‚Äîjust one. It cannot say: ‚ÄúRead this email, do this thing, sign up for a free trial, click the calendar, and also talk to these three people.‚Äù No one will ever do that. Just end it with one¬†thing.

So in sum: a curiosity-provoking subject line, a question-answering body text, and a single CTA. That‚Äôs the flow of a great cold¬†email.

If you cold call prospects, what‚Äôs the best way to actually start the¬†conversation?

It‚Äôs similar to cold emailing. The most important thing is to put yourself in the shoes of the person receiving the call. When somebody picks up the phone and they don‚Äôt know the number, they immediately think: ‚ÄúWho is this person? And are they trying to sell me something?‚Äù You need to quickly answer these two questions. State who you are, what you do, and why you‚Äôre¬†calling.

When it comes to cold calling, almost more important than what you say is how you say it. Your tonality‚Äîyour voice‚Äîwill create a certain feeling in the person that receives the call. If you sound overly nervous, you could say the greatest thing on Earth and I‚Äôm going to want to hang up. If you sound overly aggressive, you could say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to wire you a million dollars‚Äù, and I‚Äôm going to hang up. It doesn‚Äôt matter how great the words are if the way you deliver them is bad. You could say something terrible, deliver it well, and you‚Äôll get people to keep listening‚Äîand they won‚Äôt even know¬†why!

If you want to sound good on the call, you need to put yourself in a good state of mind. You want to be excited to be talking to them, because, if you‚Äôre not excited, why should they be excited to listen to you? You want to be clear and concise in your language‚Äînot too slow but not too fast. If you‚Äôre nervous, afraid, or anxious, it‚Äôll sound weird and I‚Äôll want to hang¬†up.

So: Be in a good state of mind, say hello, and explain who you are and why you‚Äôre¬†calling.

What is the average response rate, per medium, for a B2B SaaS¬†company?

When it comes to emails, you should have a minimum open rate of 20-30%. Your response rate among those people should be in the 10-20%¬†range.

When it comes to cold calls, you should have a minimum answering rate of about 15%. Your leads-to-something rate among people who answer the phone should be about¬†15%.

And again, those numbers are the lower bounds. If you are lower than that, stop doing what you‚Äôre doing because fundamentally it won‚Äôt work out. The math just won‚Äôt add up. If you‚Äôre in that state, something about what you‚Äôre doing‚Äîyour subject line or how you start the conversation‚Äîis fundamentally wrong. You need to fix it before you¬†continue.

Do you have any advice for founders trying to price their¬†product?

Charge more. If you‚Äôre an early stage founder building a B2B business, my number one piece of advice is to charge¬†more.

Most founders try to price their product so cheaply that price will never be an objection. That‚Äôs not the right way to price your¬†product.

The sweet spot in pricing is when you‚Äôre at a point¬†where:

  • 20% of the people you talk to say: ‚ÄúThis is insanely expensive! I would never buy this. This is¬†outrageous!‚Äù

  • 20% of people are like: ‚ÄúThis is kind of cheap, I would even pay more for¬†this.‚Äù

  • 60% of people really think about whether your product is worth the price. And then they conclude: ‚ÄúYeah, if it was cheaper that would be nice. But I do think the value is much higher than the¬†price.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the pricing sweet¬†spot.

How can you create urgency at the end of a web¬†demo?

There are two¬†ways.

The first way is quite common but I‚Äôm not a big fan of it. ‚ÄúHey, we‚Äôre running a promotion! If you buy before X amount of time you get Y better price, or you get Z more seats, or you get an upgraded product for the lower package, or whatever.‚Äù Some kind of a promotion that tells them: ‚ÄúHey, if you make a decision sooner rather than later there‚Äôs going to be a big lasting benefit for you.‚Äù But I dislike this approach. I think it‚Äôs¬†gimmicky.

The best way to create urgency is to understand what is urgent in this person‚Äôs professional life and then tie your product to that thing. Can your product help them accomplish this really important¬†thing?

For example, if the biggest priority that we have right now in our business is to hit our quota for numbers, and you have a marketing tool and you talk to me about how your marketing tool will help me get more likes on Twitter, there‚Äôs going to be a disconnect between my priorities and what you‚Äôre telling me. But if you could credibly explain to me how your marketing tool will help me hit my numbers? Now you have my attention. Try to figure out what‚Äôs urgent for them, and then connect your product to that¬†thing.

You can learn more about this in my free¬†ebook.

When there is human interaction in the sales process, what things should always¬†happen?

The most important thing is qualification. You‚Äôre going to have the most success if you act like an expert doctor. First you spend a lot of time trying to deeply understand who is in front of you‚Äîhow they think and feel, what the problem really is. Once you have a diagnosis for what‚Äôs going on, you need to ask yourself, can our medicine help this person? And if the answer is yes, then you‚Äôre not debating, discussing, or asking. You‚Äôre¬†prescribing.

At that point, you go: ‚ÄúI know what to do here. Here‚Äôs what you have, here‚Äôs our medicine, here are the alternatives, and here‚Äôs why ours is the best. You‚Äôre going to start taking the medicine today, and you‚Äôre going to take two per day for 14¬†days.‚Äù

If you do that, it‚Äôs not a debate anymore. I made the decision for you because I‚Äôm an expert and I want you to succeed. But in order to get to this point, the first thing I need to do is truly be convinced that our product is the best for¬†you.

A lot of people don‚Äôt take that step. They think: ‚ÄúWell, I have a product, I need to try to sell it to everybody.‚Äù So when they start interacting with customers, they instantly jump into selling mode: ‚ÄúLet me tell you about my medicine. My medicine is really great. Here‚Äôs everything that‚Äôs great about it. And also it‚Äôs really cheap.‚Äù But we haven‚Äôt had a conversation about who the person is, what pain they have, and what solutions they‚Äôve tried¬†before.

You need to spend time truly understanding them. It creates trust and credibility, so at the moment you tell them ‚ÄúI know how to fix this‚Äîmy medicine‚Äù, they‚Äôre going to believe¬†you.

The next thing I‚Äôll highlight is you need to follow up and follow through. You need to champion the relationship. The ball is never in their court. It‚Äôs always your job to help them and guide them to keep progressing to a¬†decision.

Should you charge enterprise customers for¬†pilots?

Yes. You want paid pilots. When it comes to enterprise, you want to uncover real buying intent as fast as possible. Even if the product is totally buggy or not finished yet, you should ask for a paid¬†pilot.

A lot of times, people who are insecure about their product will offer it for free as a way to feel more comfortable, as a way to offer the customer something that‚Äôs ‚Äúfair‚Äù. I would argue strongly against¬†that.

If you‚Äôre inclined to do that, don‚Äôt. Instead, ask them for money, tell them it‚Äôs completely refundable, and then don‚Äôt under any circumstance spend that money. Put it in a separate bank account. It‚Äôs not revenue until the customer has stayed for six months and says that they are happy with everything‚Äîthen you can touch the¬†money.

This has the same effect as giving your product away for free‚Äîthere‚Äôs zero risk for the customer‚Äîbut by doing this you‚Äôll weed out bad customers and you‚Äôll learn how to get customers to pay¬†you.

In the enterprise world, if you‚Äôre not putting a price tag on your product, it‚Äôs not going to be valued. A lot of times people think I‚Äôm going to start by not asking for money and then it‚Äôll organically lead to asking for money. That‚Äôs not true. You have to charge enterprise customers, no matter how early it is. If you don‚Äôt, a lot of people are going to be friendly and give you pleasant feedback. ‚ÄúOh, new technology, of course I want to see this!‚Äù It‚Äôs even going to feel like you‚Äôre accomplishing things. But you‚Äôll be wasting your¬†time.

Any tips for building and scaling a sales¬†team?

There are four¬†things.

In the beginning, you‚Äôll sell in a non-scalable way, and that‚Äôs totally fine. But eventually you have to start selling in ways that you could teach somebody else to do. That‚Äôs step¬†one.

Step two. Once you‚Äôve had some success selling in a teachable, repeatable way, hire junior salespeople, ideally in small teams of two or three. Transition from doing it yourself to teaching a few other people how to get similar¬†results.

The reason why it‚Äôs important to hire two or three people at a time is that if you just hire one person and they don‚Äôt perform well, you‚Äôre not going to know if it‚Äôs you teaching them poorly, if it‚Äôs them, or if it‚Äôs the market. But if you have two or three people, it‚Äôs very unlikely that they‚Äôre all going to perform the same way. One person will do much better than the other two, which will give you a lot of insight into what kind of person you should¬†hire.

The third step is to hire a Junior Sales Manager. This is ideally somebody that is a year or two ahead of you‚Äîsomeone who was at a startup at your stage two years ago and they became a manager there and helped grow the¬†team.

You hire this person because they‚Äôve seen the future! They‚Äôve done it before. At this point you‚Äôll have a little bit of a process, and they‚Äôll instantly know how to improve it. Once they scale the team to 15-20 people and the team has become so big that you need to have multiple Sales Managers, that‚Äôs the time to find a VP or a Senior Sales Manager, somebody who is really experienced in scaling things. They‚Äôll know how to open more sales offices, improve the compensation structure, put together a training and career plan for the company, and hire other senior¬†people.

You want to go from doing it yourself to hiring junior people to hiring the junior manager to hiring the senior manager. You can learn more in my free¬†ebook.

Any tips for selling¬†internationally?

Start by focusing on international customers who already speak your language, so that you don‚Äôt have to speak a foreign¬†language.

For us, 40% of our customers are international, but we didn‚Äôt do anything for that. Our product is still just in English and we sell it in US dollars. We actually make it hard for international customers to purchase, but they still do because our product is strong enough, good enough, valuable enough for people to want to buy¬†it.

If you‚Äôre just starting to sell internationally, I would not do a lot of over-optimization to support local languages and currencies. It‚Äôs too complex to handle at the¬†beginning.

That said, if you‚Äôre early on your journey and you do want to do local optimization, I‚Äôd suggest doing the simplest thing you can do: Take your website, and create a /germany landing page that routes based on IP address. It could still be in your native language, and it might just have a few copy changes, but you‚Äôll quickly learn whether you should further invest in¬†localization.

Any parting¬†thoughts?

Don‚Äôt think of yourself as somebody without sales experience. You have sales¬†experience!

Sales is nothing more than results-driven communication. Any time you communicate with someone and you have an end goal, you are selling. Any time someone does that to you, they are selling to you and you‚Äôre¬†buying.

Selling is just a type of communication. You‚Äôre already doing it all of the time. So don‚Äôt doubt yourself. Just do¬†it.

item.title: Building a better gov.uk, step by step
item.description:
The 'Apply for your first provisional driving licence' step by step navigation page

Since GOV.UK launched 6 years ago it has been the home of government‚Äôs online content and the starting point for online services.

Every week millions of people use GOV.UK to do complex and sometimes life-changing tasks, such as learning to drive, registering a birth or starting a business.

We want to make these tasks as easy as possible - by making content simple and user journeys intuitive. This is good for users because it makes it quicker to get things done. And it‚Äôs good for government because it reduces unnecessary contact and casework.

Why we need to look at end to end services

We know users face challenges carrying out tasks. There‚Äôs a lot of information to find for a start. Depending on the task, there might be appointments to book, forms to fill in, applications to be made and tests to take.

And what makes this even harder is that each step needs to be done at the right time and in the right order.

That‚Äôs why government needs to look at every step of this task. From the first thing the user does, to the last thing they need to do. We need to look at services from end to end.

The difficulty government faces when trying to make this easier is that people‚Äôs real-world tasks do not always fit neatly with the way government is organised into departments and agencies.

For example, a business wanting to hire their first employee needs information and services from 5 different areas of government before they can hire them:

Step Government department or agency
Check you can afford to take on an employee Department for Work and Pensions
Register as an employer HM Revenue and Customs
Check a potential employee‚Äôs right to work in the UK Home Office
Check a potential employee‚Äôs criminal record Disclosure and Barring Service
Set up a pension scheme The Pensions Regulator

Organising GOV.UK by topic and task

Rather than organise GOV.UK around the structure of government, we‚Äôve been working to organise content around user needs at scale. So, rather than being organised by department, content on GOV.UK is now organised into a single site-wide system of user-centred topics.

This topic structure will power new ways to search and browse the site, making things much easier to find.

But we want to go further - we want to make things easier to do.

So about a year ago we started experimenting with a new way for users to navigate GOV.UK. These experiments evolved into what we now call step by step navigation.

It looks like this on GOV.UK:

This page outlines the process for learning to drive a car

It means that, for the first time, we can show the user everything they‚Äôll need to do to complete a task, whether that‚Äôs Learning to drive or Employing someone.

The navigation follows you throughout your journey, indicating what to do now and next. It also shows you previous steps you might have missed. For example, getting a provisional driving licence before booking a driving theory test.

Step by step navigation appears alongside content of each step

Step by step navigation is designed to work with all existing content types and transactions on GOV.UK. Where appropriate, transactions can be broken down further using the separate task list pattern.

Developing the design

The design evolved over 8 rounds of research and iteration, including an in-depth review at the brilliant Digital Accessibility Centre in Neath.

Around half way through the lab research we began testing the pattern on GOV.UK. Analytics data showed that the first examples of step by step navigation were getting a lot of traffic. For example, learn to drive a car was used 1.24 million times in the first 6 months.

We ask users for feedback with the ‚ÄòIs this useful?‚Äô survey banner at the bottom of every page on the site. This showed users were finding it useful.

The 'Is this page useful?' banner

We also ran a remote user research study where we asked users to complete a series of tasks before and after 3 step by step journeys were published.

The study showed the step by step navigation resulted in a significant increase in users‚Äô successful task completion, as well as an increase in confidence they could use GOV.UK to find what they needed.

Scaling the approach

With encouraging data coming in, over the past 6 months we‚Äôve been working to scale this approach so it can be used for the more complex tasks users need to do. These include:

As this table shows, the content that sits within these journeys often crosses multiple government departments and we need a collaborative approach to make these journeys better for users. Creating a new process for cross-government working to support this has been equally as important as designing a new way of navigating.

Over the past 6 months we‚Äôve collaborated with more than 15 different departments to publish 25 step by step journeys.

We‚Äôre also indebted to the team at the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency who helped us map the first journeys: Learn to drive a car and Become a driving instructor when our work was still in prototype form. They‚Äôve written a great blog post about the process.

Next steps

We‚Äôll be continuing to work with departments to map and publish step by step navigation for some of the most high priority and complex user journeys within government. As we do this we‚Äôll keep a close eye on performance data to ensure this approach is still working well for users.

If you‚Äôre in a department or agency team and want to work with us to put together step by step journeys, we‚Äôd love to hear from you. Send us an email at modelling-services@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk.
